{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2989127,"name":"David","username":"David3","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/f475e1/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-11T16:39:22.054Z","cooked":"

Hello, I am trying to get some code to work with git repos. For reference we use team 2910s common folder to allow us to use our limelight and some swerve math.

We imported the regular code fine and got the common library imported into the code also. Yet whenever we try to add " compile project(‘:common’) " to the dependencies folder in build.gradle we get the following error,

A problem occurred evaluating root project ‘Basic DriveTrain’.

Could not find method compile() for arguments [project ‘:common’] on object of type org.gradle.api.internal.artifacts.dsl.dependencies.DefaultDependencyHandler

I assuming they changed the command to import projects with the new update, but then what command would I use in this scenario. Thank you for reading

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-01-11T16:39:22.054Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":141,"reads":172,"readers_count":171,"score":739.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":399693,"topic_slug":"importing-and-using-git-submodules-in-2022","display_username":"David","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50468,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/importing-and-using-git-submodules-in-2022/399693/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":2989132,"name":"Oliver","username":"ohowe","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ohowe/{size}/221361_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-11T16:44:44.797Z","cooked":"

WPILib 2022 uses gradle 7, which removed the compile function. You should use implementation instead.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-01-11T16:44:44.797Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":7,"reads":163,"readers_count":162,"score":72.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":399693,"topic_slug":"importing-and-using-git-submodules-in-2022","display_username":"Oliver","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48874,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3729 Alum"},"post_url":"/t/importing-and-using-git-submodules-in-2022/399693/2","custom_user_title":"3729 Alum","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2989273,"name":"David","username":"David3","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/f475e1/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-01-11T18:57:04.090Z","cooked":"

Thank you for this, I used " testImplementation ‘:common’ " in the build.gradle folder to allow it to build, but all of my subsystems still have errors because they cannot properly import the subsystems from common.

I know previously you had to use the command " include ‘:common’ " in the settings.gradle to allow this. But again the command is gone and I looked and cant seem to find it. Do you know what command I would use for this.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2022-01-11T18:57:04.090Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":145,"readers_count":144,"score":54.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":399693,"topic_slug":"importing-and-using-git-submodules-in-2022","display_username":"David","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48874,"username":"ohowe","name":"Oliver","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ohowe/{size}/221361_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50468,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/importing-and-using-git-submodules-in-2022/399693/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":2989280,"name":"Oliver","username":"ohowe","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ohowe/{size}/221361_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-11T19:06:14.188Z","cooked":"

In your settings.gradle you should have include 'common' (see this) and I’m pretty sure you should be using implementation not testImplementation because testImplementation is meant for your dependency’s used in unit testing (see this).

Thank you so much. Those articles helped me better understand how to do this. I am having some troubles with some of the imports in common. They work when a separate repository but when I add it in it does not. But I will try and fix that tonight. Thank you for the help

Hello I have one last question if that is ok. I have gotten the src folder to work correctly with a little modification of the common app as a github dependency. But I would also like for the robot folder of this program to work too.

Previously as seen here GitHub - FRCTeam2910/Common: Common code for all robots the command to add the robot folder was just to add a " :robot " to the build.gradle and gradle settings. Yet now when I attempt this I get told

Build file ‘C:\Users\Student\Documents\GitHub\2021-2022 Code\BuildSeason\DriveTrain-Test\common\robot\build.gradle’ line: 10

  • What went wrong:

A problem occurred evaluating project ‘:common:robot’.> No signature of method: build_6ucybw6o0nb6474t0zrxxna6a.wpi() is applicable for argument types: (build_6ucybw6o0nb6474t0zrxxna6a$_run_closure1) values: [build_6ucybw6o0nb6474t0zrxxna6a$_run_closure1@4db4afa1]
Possible solutions: wait(), wait(long), uri(java.lang.Object), run(), run(), any()

Looking at this I believe it means that it cannot find the robot folder like in previous versions yet I have looked through the articles you have linked at last nights practice and I couldn’t find anything like that. Is there a solution to this I am not seeing.

So common’s build is executing after your project’s build for some reason. (You can see this by running gradle build --info). This is an issue as your project depends on common. One easy way to fix it (somewhat) is to just run gradle :common:robot:build. This’ll work fine if you have no plans to change common. This doesn’t solve the root cause of the issue of dependencies not being built before the dependent (normally gradle does this automatically but not here for some reason) however.
